text: Howdy everyone, I'm an American living in Paris very interested in democratizing the development of apps and programs. My current controversial opinions/hypotheses are that in most companies design and product really do most of the "programming" (but little of the coding), developers have developed internal models of the subsets of Turing machines that behave well but we haven't made those explicit, and category theory may provide a useful way to model programs and guarantee properties under composition (but currently feels primarily descriptive).

text: Welcome Don!  I'm an American who lived for a long time in Nice, France.  My family and I really miss it there.  Like you (and a lot of us here), I also am all about democratizing development / "access to software construction", simplifying development to its necessary complexity which isn't nearly as complex as we like to think it is.  The chaotic nonsense of current development highlights that, while we may know what we're doing, we don't really understand what we're doing.  Again -- welcome!

elements.text: Welcome Don!  I'm an American who lived for a long time in Nice, France.  My family and I really miss it there. text:
Hi everybody, I just found this community today through the Whole Code Catalog that was getting shared on Twitter, adding the podcast to my list as well. I’m an engineer working on design and prototyping of voice user interfaces at Adobe, primarily on Adobe Xd and previously at my startup Sayspring that focused on Alexa and Google Home.

Tend to stick to HN and Twitter (@scottwernerd), and ran into <@UCUSW7WVD> online a while back through Ribbonfarm and his blog. Actually got into an argument the other day around code style that ended with me sending someone a link to one of your old blog posts :slightly_smiling_face:

Anyway, current side project is working on an idea around reading and exploring code I got from the end of The Timeless Way of Building. I don’t have the book with me, but the drawings on the right side on page 488 are the key idea - being able to visualize how code evolves over time at different levels (project, file, class, function, etc). I’m still in the early stages, so don’t really know if anything interesting is going to fall out, but happy to chat more if that sounds interesting to anyone.

elements.text:

I’m an engineer working on design and prototyping of voice user interfaces at Adobe, primarily on Adobe Xd and previously at my startup Sayspring that focused on Alexa and Google Home.

Tend to stick to HN and Twitter (@scottwernerd), and ran into
online a while back through Ribbonfarm and his blog. Actually got into an argument the other day around code style that ended with me sending someone a link to one of your old blog posts

Anyway, current side project is working on an idea around reading and exploring code I got from the end of The Timeless Way of Building. I don’t have the book with me, but the drawings on the right side on page 488 are the key idea - being able to visualize how code evolves over time at different levels (project, file, class, function, etc). I’m still in the early stages, so don’t really know if anything interesting is going to fall out, but happy to chat more if that sounds interesting to anyone.
